Early Access Review

This is one of these where you feel sad to not recommend it.
Let me start by stating that I believe the developers can and probably will fix any issues that crop up in the game - I can see the effort they put into it, and hopefully I can explain why I don't recommend it at the moment.
This is not a simple YES / NO review. So I advise you to read further before downvoting or thinking the game is bad.

For an Early Access title, it's a very well polished product. The graphics are good, the interface is nice, and the audio is great, and there's few bugs.
However, even though the game is well made and has good potential if further developed, its current core gameplay is repetitive and not really fun. Which is exactly why I can't recommend it: it's not a matter of specific, isolated issues. The CORE of the game feels pointless at this time.

COMBAT: Battles are EXTREMELY slow, repetitive, unsatisfying and not rewarding as one might think. I'm sad to say it's the worst pacing and balancing I've experienced from this sort of FTL-insipired games. It feels like Sid Meyer's Pirates in space (which is good and could be a lot of fun) with a slight touch of FTL.
Even after I got the most expensive combat ship, and decent skill on battles, it still felt wrong, and kind of boring. Enemies may surrender and offer you a good amount for their lives, however, which is a great thing to see when it works - very few games I played have such feature.

TRADING: The game doesn't provide enough info to make sense of the economy. And even though it follows a basic supply/demand and consumption/production cycle, there's no influence in the game universe beyond that. Trading is a simple mindless grind, which wouldn't be that big of a deal if it could be automated. And once you figure out a good run, you can have everyhing in the game after some mindless hauling that shouldn't take more than a couple of hours.

Those are the two core aspects of the game, and both feels shallow - which is weird, because the presentation of the game is amazing. However, all the systems are in place, and both Combat and Trading can be further expanded, balanced or fixed, because the design isn't FUBAR. So there IS hope for Cosmonautica.

I did enjoy the research feature and how it's implemented - In my opinion, it's a pretty unique system. And the semi-realistic orbital" flight is a fresh take on space flight in games.

Unfortunately this then leads to items being stuck in your cargohold which you have purchased but then can't find anywhere in the system that will buy them.

Levelling up your crew members is iffy. At the point of level up you are granted a skill point to increase that crew members abilities. Again unfortunately, once you've found that out and decide you don't want them to start a new skill set and you just want them to improve in their current job you find you can't, as there is no cancel button and you have to accept.

reviewText:
Cosmonautica is... almost the game i've been looking for for many years.  It's very significant that although at this stage, the game does crash about once an hour, I don't seem to mind (and this usually causes me to rant).

Cosmonautica is a cute, humourous game where you manage your (at the start, very shoddy) spaceship and crew. There's trading, smugglin, passenger transportation and fighting. You can upgrade your ship's rooms by installing a science module and hiring a scientist.

The trading takes a while to get used to, but after a bit of practice it's possible to make a profit margin. However, this wll not be sufficient to amass a fortune: i find that at the start it's best to concentrate on a combination of trading and passenger transportation to make a living. Fighting is best left to a little later, as your starting ship and crew aren't worth much in a fight yet :)

All in all, a very very nice game, with the potential to be a great game if the developpers keep adding features, missions and new upgrades for your ship. (Maybe even ground 'away' missions?)

PROS:
- Nice cartoony graphics
- Funny, without ever becoming obnoxious
- Good balance between trading/fighting/transportation...
- Some learning curve at the start but not too hard after a few hours' practice
- Very addictive as you want to keep improving your ship, crew and fortune

CONS:
- Occasional 'freeze' crashes (the game litterally just left early access so I imagine they will fix this soon)
- The fights do feel a bit 'light'

WISHLIST:
I feel the game could be really great but just needs to be 'fleshed out' some. So for what it's worth, here's my wishlist :)
- FIx the 'freeze' crash issues
- Make some more variation for the crew (both graphical and in personality complexity, backstory etc...)
- Flesh the fights out some more: these feel a bit 'light', no real sense of danger or damage (some sound changes and a slight speed up of pace perhaps?)
- More and more diverse missions available on space stations - possibly even longer missions requiring more steps
- 'Away' missions on planetary surfaces.

Anyway, I heartily recommend this game to lovers of Sid Meier's Pirates, the Hitch Hiker's Guide or Firefly!

reviewText:
Have played a fair amount of this pre-release and post-release. There are lots of positives here but not enough currently to keep my interest. Here are a few headlines if you're on the fence:

PRO'S

Decent crossover of SIMS/Space Trader.
A reasonable amount of ships to save up for.
Lots of star systems to explore, though this isn't really encouraged as much as it could be in the story mode.
Graphics are cartoony and bright.
Missions are fairly varied.

CON'S

Lots of crashes - even after 'finished' release.
As mentioned in other reviews - economy is fairly static and doesn't always make sense. A planet that exports robots only has 10 tons at any given time? How is that an export system?
Lots of bugs - trade bugs will regularly put you into a negative balance. Mission text doesn't always reflect mission outcomes,
Combat - DULL, DULL, DULL. No speed up option, most fights end up in either a stalemate or are a simple matter of 'Charge all guns blazing'.
SIMS element is underplayed - characters don't really interact enough.
Trading is incredibly tedious - see above on static economy. So I bought a ship with 80 units of space but the market only has 4 units of what I need? And it only regenerates at 2 units per 2 days? EXCELLENT.
Autosave feature means that if something goes badly wrong (see negative cash balance bugs) then you are completely scuppered.
Some grammatical errors and generally unpolished text entries.

It's a shame - the game tries to shine in two genres but doesn't really take off in either. Hopefully this game will get more patches and content as it goes along - for now I would only pick this up if you want to grab it while its on sale and you don't mind learning the ropes of an unfinished game that has a lot of potential.

- DG.

Early Access Review

The game scratched my itch for an trading and exploration game, but i feel like i reached the bottom to soon.

I enjoyed the 9h of gameplay i got out of it so far. The graphics and animation quality is very impressive, and I like the design work very much. Buying resources, travelling and reselling them for a profit feels good. Ontop of that, there are missions on every planet, e.g. to transport people to a certain planet. However, the variety among these missions is extremely limited. It feels like they are always the same ~10 missions, no matter which planet.

I also do not quite understand the point of the additional solar systems one can travel to. They have certain shifts in the distribution of resources you can buy and sell, but offer nothing new at all otherwise. The quests are the same, the goods are essentially the same as well.

Also, I got through my games - so far - without requiring any weapons what so ever. I think forcing the player to aquire some weapons as defense would be a good idea, i.e. by throwing the player into combat every now and then. This happened for me once, but i could easily flee without any repercussions. This is a shame, because forcing more combat on the player could be a way of disturbing them from the much more efficient strategy of peacefully buying and reselling expensive goods.

There are still a good number of bugs, too. From missing planet names in the main scenario mission descriptions to a straight up crash (happened once, and was mitigated by the apparently very regular autosaving).

I only had 2 different ships, I never did any hacking, I avoided combat without any problem. And still, I do not feel too much incentive in going those routes either, because I don't expect to find anything new.

Sid Meier's Pirates created depth through Diplomatic relationships, progression of the main character (becoming the best pirate, avenging your family), and showed variety through a number of minigames. Both variety and depth are unfortunately lacking in Cosmonautica.

In total, I do not regret having spent 10Euros for an enjoyable 9h of gameplay. And maybe, if some variety is added until release or after, I might revisit it for another 10h. So I would still recommend to anyone who likes space adventure and economic games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is a basic trade simulator. Nothing more (yet?). The art style is wonderful and lured me into buying the game, but the gameplay loop is very boring (to emphazise: it's boring, boring, boring!). So what do you really do in this game?

1. You stop at planets and trade a few goods (not that entertaining).
2. You watch (mostly) passivly, whilst your crew is in transit between planets. They work and poop and sleep and that's about it. They don't interact with each other, you (the player) can't really do anything but to double the speed while in transit.
3. Go to 1.
3.1. Combat. Has to be reworkd in a big way, because right now it's sluggish, unintuitive, slow and really not fun.

People who compare COSMONAUTICA to FTL are simply lying to your face. It has NOTHING of FTL, except a crew that flies a spaceship, but the similarities end here. You don't have to manage your crew, you don't have to position them, you don't interact with them. It's like watching an aquarium. An aquarium you don't have control over.

The main problem is, that I can't see how the developer want to salvage the gameplay. The graphics are absolutely lovely, but tbh it looks like the graphics were here first and the actual gameplay is an afterthought.



TL;DR

+Graphics are wonderful.

-It is NOT like FTL in any shape.
-It's a very simple trading simulator.
-Combat is terrible (slow and unintuitive).
-It gets boring very, very quickly.

First game I bought in 2015. First purchase I deeply regret since about three years.

So yeah. Save your money. Maybe it will evolve to an actually interesting game (doubtful), but right now it's not worth your money.

I wanted to like this title more than I did, what with its elements of management, space, trading and designing your own vessel layout in ant farm view, it ticked a lot of boxes to my liking. Even the characters and art style look fine.

But its the mechanics that let this game down.

reviewText:
A fun, quirky game that offers players the opportunity to trade, smuggle, be a taxi, fight battles, manage a crew, and purchase/upgrade new ships ... IN SPACE! Here's a quick breakdown:

PROS
-Nice graphics, very polished and cartoonish
-Very catchy soundtrack
-Plenty of research options and the ability to upgrade your ship, find new solar systems, etc.
-Each crew member is unique in their own way in appearance, personality, and attributes
-Missions to earn money in a variety of ways
-A decent main quest to follow instead of just flying around aimlessly (if that's your thing, there is sandbox mode, too.)
-Each planet and solar system is unique in its own way and consumes, produces, and has a ban on different things
-Some Sim-like aspects to your crew in that you have to provide for their needs to keep them happy and working
-Fast forward time speed option to cut down on long trips for the impatient player in all of us
-The game doesn't take itself too seriously and has humor throughout
-The devs are active, helpful, and take their players concerns seriously. They want to make the game worthy of praise

CONS
-Still pretty buggy and crashes occasionally, but not to the point of making the game unplayable
-The missions are very repetitive and predictable
-Space battles aren't that exciting
-Moderate learning curve

SUGGESTIONS
-Would be great if there were diplomacy options or the chance to establish your own production/trading stations
-The option to create a small fleet or galactical trading empire would be a plus
-More weapons and room options
-Much larger variety of missions

All in all, if you like economical sci-fi simulators, this is a pretty sweet game. I'm sure it will develop over time to be even better. It's definitely a good start. If you liked Sid Meier's Pirates!" or Firefly

reviewText:
Note: This game has been given to me for free for review purposes.OverviewCosmonautica is a space economy simulator in which you take control of a small ship and sail through the galaxies, trading, transporting people, fighting baddies or by doing black market business, and earn money to customize, upgrade and manage your vessel, either by researching rooms and improvements or training your staff (or hiring better ones). Overall, this is a nice game which is what many players wanted to have from a game.

The Pros:Humorous - This game has uplifting, groovy music, caricaturized characters, and funny dialogue options. It's clear that this is the kind of loose simulator that doesn't take it too seriously, but surprisingly enough, it is packed with features. I liked that it was able to offer so much versatility while still keeping it fun.

The Art Style - One of the first things you notice is the brightly colored, cartoony graphics that the game uses. For some reason it just feels right for what this game is trying to achieve, considering the humorous nature of the game. The game runs very smoothly and has a decent set of graphical options and resolutions.

Freedoooom! - The game has two modes: Campaign and Sandbox. Other than that campaign mode has predetermined solar systems and a short questline, whereas sandbox randomises your start and contains no starting questline, they are identical in gameplay and neither restrict you. You are free to do as you please, which is to be expected from a simulation game.

Randomised Versatility - There are many missions to undertake, goods to buy and sell, people to hire or fire and galaxies to explore, and the best thing is that this game randomises everything! Proceduraly generated Universe and random missions and crew-for-hire at all space stations.

Excellent UI - The user interface is very well made. It manages to remain very organised and intuitive despite the fact that it displays a lot of info. The font is nice, the colors are well used, and it has a hint of Borderlands to it.

Steam Integration - Apart from lacking co-op, this game has the basic Steam needs: Achievements, Trading Cards, and most importantly, Steam Cloud.
The Cons:Grind Fest! - This game is very fun at first, but then it gets kind of repetitive, especially because everything must be researched!!! And this is an aspect that I really don't get. Ok, you need to research the outer rings of the solar systems in your computer to casually explore it, but why do I need to research an extended bedroom or bathroom or a kitchen, that I won't even install, but the people at the shipyard. It's like passing near Ikea but going to buy raw materials and reverse engineer a piece of furniture, then going to Ikea and have them sell it to you. What?! Also, these researches take time, a lot of time, and during that time you are bound to grind away, trading through space. I wish it was less grindy and a bit... realistic? Also, trading is what you will mostly end up doing throughout the game, so if you like this kind of activity, great! But if you are a more action oriented gamer, this game is not for you.

Unsatisfactory Combat - No matter how skilled your crew is, they will somehow find a way to screw battles up. Some of them straight off go to sleep while others fire missiles at the enemy, and sometimes the Pilot will just move in random directions, even fleeing despite the fact that you would clearly win. The combat system needs more polish.

You... Don't Exist! - You are a god-like being, almost controling your crew like the Sims, but you don't exist. You don't appear, nor have a room in the space ship. It's like you are telepathically making decisions, which is a little disappointing. I mean, it would have been great to have yourself as a no-fee employee and improve your skills and such over time. But the game and everything in it treats you like you do exist, such as NPCs and mission dialogues.

Impossible Perfect Late Game - This game almost tries to tell you that you shouldn't aspire to be the best - because if you do upgrade your ship and your crew to great heights, you will be very sad to find out that your upkeep will be so high, that it's almost impossible to make ends meet.
ConclusionSo, is this game worth it? Well, yes and no. I recommend this game to anyone who likes space exploration and trading, and enjoys micromanaging everything, even if you have to do the same things over and over again. People who like trading games will surely like this one. For people who want the complete space experience however, this isn't the game for you. It features lots of great elements from other great games and tries to cram them all in one, but something is still missing. The poorly made battle system and the long wait of pointless research make it enjoyable only for some.

Early Access Review

I don't have a lot of hours logged into this game yet, nor have I completed the campaign. Still I have had fun playing this, as well as fustration.

Gameplay consists of the player being the captain of a starship with your goal being to amass as much money as you can. Your ship travels through the galaxy with you being able to view it and your crew in an ant farm type view. The missions offered on the different stations provide the most stable source of income, but you can try your hand at playing the trabing game between imports and exports. Or if your ship is set up in the right way you can set out to hunt down pirates or smuggle illegal goods.

Here is something that I was disappointed about. You can't capture criminals, there is a bounty-like system but it isn't as gratifying as it should be. Nor do you need to deal with people trying to raid your shipments. Pirates like to pick fights with you but if you bribe them they just leave you alone.

While I'm on the topic here are some other things I didn't like:
-no character avatar. Sorry capt'n you're just the ghost of the ship
-you don't interact with the crew. You are limited to setting the work schedule and the promotions. Can't be having the      pilot and the cook go off for alone time ya' know?
-battles don't have much finesse about them. Maybe because you're supposed to be a trading vessel but still.
-You can't pick a career. What if I wanted to be a pirate huh?
-There isn't much to do when traveling between worlds
--(this is the big one) In sandbox mode you can't change any of the settings. Random really means random.
I have a small gripe about always pulling into a space station, but I don't think it's that big of a game killer.

But it's not all bad. There are some things that were pretty good:
+The trading system is pretty diverse and believable
+Your crew can be as diverse or inclusive as you want. A greater option of aliens would have been nice.
+Humor isn't obnoxious, nor are the pop culture references unlike some other games.
+challenge curve gets kind of steep, but never feels unfair.

Unless there's a curve ball down the line this game will get rather tedious fast unless you can learn to enjoy the challenge. Even though I listed more negatives than positive I like this game for my own reasons and I recomend this to everyone, even if only to try it out a little. Bottomline: don't think about where it came from, just take the money and run!

reviewText:
OK so there's plenty of bad and good for this game. Let me lay my opinion on the line here from a couple of hours of initial gameplay (Which I have no doubt will grow to a few more [albeit modest] hours in the future)

This is a casual game by far. In that sense I've personally found it rather zen. You've no doubt gotten a fair idea of what the gameplay is. You manage a crew in a basic sense aboard your vessel. You travel around, first, one solar system trading, smuggling and fighting to accrue money. This cash goes towards bigger vessels and more capability to extend your activities further abroad. Beyond that overall premise, you have to manage the crew you use to staff said craft and their relationships and needs. As they become more skilled they require more effort to keep them satisfied (A feature which, thanks to a recent addition of bonuses, you can come close to bypassing to an extent early on if the money is flowing),

If you are someone like me that's happy to provide a narrative (Other Dwarf Fortress and Paradox Grand Strategy players will understand) for the game you'll enjoy this, but superficially. There's plenty of capacity to do so but it is provided with a quite limited depth.

There's a comedic element to the game which works quite well, but I personally don't take that in too much as (as mentioned above) I enjoy supplying my own narrative to the game. That being said it provides a level of enjoyment to the game even if it can be found to reduce the 'immersion' factor.

To give a TL;DR overview though, if you are looking for a relaxing game set around Captaining a ship and crew while jaunting around getting into whatever adventures you see fit, this is a great game to destress to. If you want more complexity in your zero-G adventuring, check out the X series or EVE online.

All being said and done, with the above caveats, I will recommend this title as a simple, enjoyable and satisfying experience. Additionally, the devs seem to be taking comments on board and working to adjust gameplay in an ongoing fashion.

PS. A couple of things that I think this game requires:
- The ability to speed up time to a greater extent
- More intricate and involved crew requirements and procedural command events (There are some, I hope there will be more as I go on)

Overall, once again, I've found this a relaxing and satisfying game. It will likely get repetative in the future (And I will update my review accordingly) however that's the lot of a ship captain in reality isn't it? Haul cargo, wash rinse and repeat with a dash of combat and smuggling to make it interesting. If the devs continue to update accordingly, it will continue to satisfy unless you're looking for an ultra-deep and complex experience. In that case, look elsewhere.

First came The Sims, then Sims Medieval, and now it's...SIMS IN SPACE!

Or at least that's what you'll instantly think when you start this game.

Looking past that one flaw...or feature, depending on how you look at it...the game will easily fill the occassional itch of armchair space captains who just want to wander space completely on their own terms and play style. It has both a storymode and sandbox mode, and all of the ports of call have missions to undertake if you feel so inclined. If not, then just fill you holds with cigarettes and beer and head out.

Has a multitude of solar systems to discover, quite a few ship layouts in three basic styles; trader, cruise ship, or warship and many room types and upgrades.

All in all, a fun, relaxing, casual space-faring romp for those players who just want to play the way they personally enjoy, and really, what can be better than that?

reviewText:
It's billed as a 'Space Trading Adventure', but this buggy game is a poor port of a poor mobile game, with very little adventure and very little trading.

On the surface, it seems interesting. You have to keep your interstellar crew happy while they zip around the galaxy, fighting and trading. So it has a Sims aspect to it. But here, as in so many other areas, the execution is poor. As your 'Sims' level up, they demand more amenities to keep them happy. But once you install the required room on your ship, the problem goes away, forever. There is no tension involved. Crew unhappy, buy room, problem solved.

The whole game is like this. At the beginning of the game, you want a shooter who can also clean or repair, so they always have a job. So this is a bit of leveling up strategy, or someone to look for when hiring crew. But later in the game, you can get robots to do the menial work, removing the need to bother with it. Strategy removed.

As for the trading, it doesn't make sense. Some planets consume, some produce. But there is no overview of this. What's more, it's not very lucrative, compared to...

Combat. Here is where the game is completely broken. Combat involves 'tapping' buttons at the right time. There's not much to it. But compared to trading, it's insanely profitable. There really is no reason to trade. Once you have their hull down to 15%, they will be on the phone to you, offering 40k, 50k, 60k to let them live. Compared to the 7k you can make hauling cigarettes across the map and back. And once you've figured this out, in a matter of hours you'll have the most expensive ship in the game. And then, there is no game anymore.

Yes, there's a story, whatever.

Finally, it crashes. A lot. There are in game bugs as well.

Stay away.

I love the idea of this game, but the implementation leaves a lot to be desired. I can not recommend this game.

Cosmonautica does a lot of things right, unfortunately it does several critical things wrong.  The humor, the graphics, the sound, the visuals are all spot on and to be admired. It's a fun game to get into. But once you do, and get a little bit into the game, the flaws begin to show through and severely limit your ability to play.

The biggest flaw I came across was a severe lack of balance and difficulty. This is a simple change that could be fixed with the addition of a difficulty slider. See, when you have a game where you trade for credits, that economic model needs to be spot on. Unfortunately even if you do everything 100% correct, the profit margins on trading are razor thin.

In two hours of play, making only positive trades, I barely was able to re-attain the amount of capital (20k credits) I started the game with as seed money. Another hour and a half later and I was still only around the 30k. Now on it's own, this might be acceptable for some. A game where you have to micromanage razor thin profit margins and grind out credits might be acceptable. But this was all while I was making perfect trades and always turning profit. If you take a loss, at any time, it's absolutely devastating. After 3.5 hours play I got stopped by a cop and had a 15% chance of getting caught. RNG came up and I got caught. This caused me to fail my current quest, which penalized me credits, lost all my cargo, and was banned from that world for 15 days. The effects of this were absolutely devastating to my game, knocking me down well below the 20k mark just to get to a new planet, refitted, and get a new hold of cargo. IE one random chance event, that could only happen 3 out of 20 times, and I'd lost around two hours of gameplay.

The further issue in the game is in the absolutely horrible combat system. You run out of ammo FAR too quickly, far more quickly than you can possibly take out even the weakest of pirates.  Forget about harder difficulty ships, you don't stand a chance. Ramming doesnâ€™t even work, because the AI can avoid you forever.

I think Cosmonautica has the potential for a good game, but it feels like an unfinished beta at this point.  I would HIGHLY recommend against buying this game at the current state it's in.  (v1.2)

reviewText:
--Initial look--

I first found this game on steam after playing 'FTL'(which I got bored of very quickly), then playing 'Space rogue'(which is basically FTL with better graphics but buggy as hell). The pics looked good, adds a trading and exploration element, as well as the ability to change up your ship in ports to suit your needs.

All this combined with the fact that it was a steam greenlight game, the reviews were mixed(most of the bad ones just stupid little gripes about things that didn't even effect game play) and is currently $14.99 USD on steam, meant that it was worth the risk to buy and give it a go.

--Graphics--

At first glance I was disappointed with the graphics.

That was until I took a closer look at the way it was done, the creators of Cosmonautica have taken a large attention to tiny little details and overlaid the entire game with a filter that resembles the horizontal lines you used to get with old LCD screens. Which in my opinion gives the game that old sci fi feel, like you're overseeing the play of the game from your own consol on the ship.

--In game world--

The map is large and unless you're playing in story mode is procedurally generated for that extra replay value. Each solar system map has four rings with a few planets, the starter ring and the next three that you can research to gain access too. Then you have your star chart, you start with one quadrant which usually has three solar systems in it, then you can research further star charts and expand your travels in world.

--Game play/Controls--

Controls are a simple point and click interface, most things are fairly self explanatory and everything else you just need to click on for a explanation or description.

Game play is fun and addictive. You start off with a little ship and some money and have to fit out your ship from the start, choosing either to take a few passengers, a lot of cargo or split the difference. You will need to hire staff based on skills and wages, with added traits which can determine how well your staff actually get along.

It all comes down to managing your staffs well being, meeting deadlines(or suffer a penalty) and making money to improve your ship or just buy and fit out a new one. Then latter on when you have researched a little and have enough crew to man weapons of shields you can ship goods into bad zones(careful of customs and their heavy fines), hunt pirates or just become a pirate yourself.

--Story--

Story mode is fun, you have a slightly psychotic robot parrot as your companion who gives you comical hints on what to do next or just randomly develops red eyes and starts screaming at you, sometimes in command code(and then apologises).

--Overall--

When I first started playing it had some bugs, but nothing that affected game play, usually just little things like a crew member doing one thing and the character tile saying they are doing another, that being said the developers at Chasing Carrots are at the top of their game and have any bugs fixed really fast.

This is a great game and did everything the other games should have done and with a better look, style and with a comical twist(like space ships being modeled after actual ships).

If you have played FTL or Space rogue and just got bored of it being the exact same thing over and over and over, give Cosmonautica a try.

Again currently on Steam for $14.99 USD, the Apple store for $6.99 and Goggle play for $8.99 USD

Graphics: 8/10 For style.
In-game world: 9/10
Game play: 8/10
Story: 7/10
Overall Score: 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Written October 2 2014: Cosmonautica is still in the Early access stages of its development, but what I've seen so far looks pretty solid:  there's an organic feelling to the local economy, a tongue in cheek sense of humor that feels right with what they're trying to do, and a good vibe to the crew and ship that give it a lot of personality (right down to the religions your crew belong to).

That said:

- The game does crash a fair bit (Probably 4 or 5 times in the last hour)
- Some of the missions you pick up aren't particularly clear on how to resolve them (i.e.: Told to kill a pirate who was coming to the station I was at... waited for a few cycles for the pirate to show up, got bored and left and was then revealed I had to leave the station to engage them).
- Would be nice to see more danger associated with certain cargo. Hauling fertilizer may not yield high profits, but if moving guns meant getting the attention of pirates and grabby governments, I might think twice.
- One mechanic in the game is that a more skilled crew needs more things which is neat (i.e.: the 5 star pilot needs entertainment, exercise, social exchanges, etc... compared to the 1 star who needs a toilet, food, and a place to sleep). That said; I cannot see what the difference is between the 1 star and the 5 star which makes the need for developing your crew a little moot (i.e.: Maybe a 5 star pilot keeps the ship from being hit in combat and plots faster trips, the better mechanic makes the ships engines faster, the medic buffs everyone so everyone does better, etc)
- On the same note, I found that the more skilled my crew was (5 star pilot for instance), the more difficult it was to keep their morale even somewhat positive. There are just too many needs that accumulate and the time it takes to service each one (while the others continue to increase) don't leave a lot of room to do anything but go from one need to the next. Possible solution may be to have certain rooms service multiple needs at the same time (the club could be exercise, social, and entertainment and the chef's lounge could be social, food, and fatigue, etc...), or to slow the rate of need accumulation.
- Despite the variety of planets, would like to see a greater emphasis on more illegal products which might force different paths through space (Weapons could be illegal in a particular area requiring you to step around them, etc...). At the moment, Narcotics is the only product that falls into that category, but its implemented very well.
- Would like to see 'me' in the game. In the sense that I'm a disembodied 'thing' that tells the crew what to do and where to go, yet I'm not an actual crew member. Would be good to create your avatar, pick the skill you start with, then filling in gaps amongst the crew as you proceed.
- Would like to see more ship variety and the ability to rename my own ship.

Now all this said and done; I'm writing this review early into their cycle so I'm guessing lots of the above will get changed or addressed, but for now I'm happy to recommend this game to anyone who wants to bend the 'verse to their whims.

reviewText:
SimTower meets Privateer

Interesting combination of game elements in a manner that shouldn't work, but somehow does.  Interesting range of ships (but needs to be bigger and include more classes), the commodity model is reasonable (albeit rather basic), very similar to the Privateer model of base types, except that this game allows for bases to be multiple 'types'.

Crew recruitment and requirements can be counter-intuitive and frustrating, especially with limited options at each base and the need to build up a large crew over time.  I would have thought that having a crew that eats different things would lead to better harmony as they're not all competing for the same subset of the food supply (but that's me I guess).

Upskilling crew has one SERIOUS limitation; you don't get to choose the additional skill you would like a crew member to learn if you want to multi-skill them.  This to me is a massive flaw and not representative of the real world, where bosses have a large say in what development paths you follow.  Additionally, the random assignment of special attributes is great during upskilling except that it introduces negative traits quite a bit.  I understand that as people become more specialised they can become less adept in other areas, but given that it's an upskill, at least have special attributes balanced; +1 something, -1 something else.

Combat (before you're ready for it) is even more frustrating because the flee move doesn't seem to actually allow you to evade combat; it should if the game is to be properly balanced IMHO)

Mission choices are extremely limited (like Privateer) but the class of missions seems to be even smaller.  Combat, smuggling, or delivery (cargo or passengers).  That would be fine if there was a larger range of destinations and missions to choose from, but there isn't.

Finally, I think the biggest concern I have is that the Devs seem to have moved on to new projects, announcing there is no longer full time support going into this game.  Don't get me wrong; I like the game, but it's incomplete.  There are still some crashes that occur semi-regularly in the game, and there needs to be more content developed for the game to increase choice and range.  I'd like to see more effort put into getting this game right before new games receive focus.

Pros:  Reasonably simple trading model, nice touch of ship management with crew, so long as it doesn't impact the flow of the game.

Cons: Frustrating crew recruitment and upskilling, poor range of choice generally (ships, missions, new crew, pretty much everything), and no more full time support from the devs.

While I recommend this game, I'd love a button for 'undecided'.  It's about a 55/45 split for me at the moment, although I intend to put more time into it to see if familiarity and learning curve change the balance somewhat.  Original fusion of ideas, but needs more polish.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Nice, casual space trading game, not for people seeking challenge or complex economy sims.
This is a nice, relaxing casual game which is worth the price if what you are looking for is a moderately entertaining game where you click things and numbers go higher.
While it is not as shallow as an actual clicker game, after a few hours of having fun with the game you slowly realize that there isn't really that much that can go wrong, which makes the already dull combat system feel pointless (you can also usually skip combat simply by communicating with your enemy and he will let you go, sometimes for free, sometimes for like 300 credits, which is basically nothing).
Your crew never really has any real complaints (and you can completely ignore their needs for a loong time without consequence anyway) and you can easily replace anyone.
Random events make no impact as they come unexpectedly but are explained in such a weird way that the player will often not understand what the result means in gameplay terms.
The character traits of your crewmates really seems completely cosmetic, you dont see any interaction between NPC's like them talking or doing anything social aboard the ship (I guess autism is a big thing in the future)
Trading is ok, since its very relaxing, but there is not enough economy simulation to really make it interesting (You can mostly sell the same things at the same prices and the same places, limited only by the amount of the commodity a planet can store)
The graphics are pretty much sufficient for this kind of game, it has a friendly cartoonish look with a few nice details to make it feel more alive but i can imagine people not liking the style.
All in all, I would recommend this game to people who are looking for something to pass time without needing much commitment or quick reaction time. If you enjoy casual trading and space exploration games and aren't interested in the mechanics behind what is happening in a game you will probably spend 10 enjoyable hours with this title.

reviewText:
Fun but flawed
Cosmonautica deserves to be recommended, but only in a Steam sale, and here's why.

I picked Cosmonautica up after discovering Space Colony, but whilst both offer essentially the same prospect of The Sims meets an RTS in space, they are very different beasts. For those not familiar with Space Colony (in which case you're missing a treat) it's a micro-management city builder with some fairly basic but well-developed Sims dropped in - give them what the need and they'll mostly look after themselves, but you still need to intervene to keep them friendly (and more) towards each other, and occassionally to restore their sanity. The first couple of missions are a bit clunky as the game wants you to know that this is important stuff, but later on you're so pushed for time building your base, and managing resources, plant life and alien incursions, that keeping a happy crew becomes both a challenging and enjoyable element of the game. And as well as the two-pronged (civil / military) split campaign you get a good variety of challenge maps and an editor in the package.

Unfortunately this may have set my bar rather high.

Cosmonautica is more like the Sims meets Pirates!, but it doesn't quite hit the mark, and now I've played enough of it I'm realising why, and it's fundamental flaw is in pandering too much to casual gaming. The (single) campaign starts out promisingly enough but it falls down in a few key areas.

The crew management is essentially limited to picking the right team (tip: make sure they all eat the same food and don't promote them beyond level 2 until they can at least sleep, eat, wash, exercise, play games and take pills and they'll never fall out or complain about anything). The biogs are nice but very short, which wouldn't matter were it not for the fact that the game offers hardly any opportunities for them to stand out individually.

The ship battles are also disappointing, and even more so because it wouldn't take much to fix them. Here Cosmonautica really wants to be Pirates!, but the touch-friendly interface (with no keyboard controls) limits manouvering to basic commands (circle left / right, etc) and Pirates! fans will be bashing their cursor pads in frustration. Without better controls battles basically amount to working out whether to fight or flee, and then slowly getting close enough to begin playing whack-a-mole with command icons until the other ship gives up or blows up. Battles just aren't fun, and all it needed to do was copy Pirates!

And finally there's the downtime when travelling between planets. Even if there was much to the crew management, travelling in normal time would bore you to death, and travelling in fast time doesn't give you a big enough gap to think through and make any decisions. So trips are reduced to the sort of 20-30 second turn times you'd complain about on a turn-based strategy.

In short, Cosmonautica is a missed opportunity. I've not completed it yet so have no idea how far in I am, but I've got myself a nice cruiser and unlocked all the science upgrades except for whatever's left of the galaxy hexes, and I'm going to finish the campaign and probably grind my way to buying a top tier ship, but with only a sandbox as an alternative to the campaign I'm not sure I'll be coming back afterwards.

It's still very polished, and as one of the more involving casual games it's fun, but put it up against even an old RTS or trader and you'll soon see its flaws.

reviewText:
I like this game, despite apparently everyone else hating it. I am really into the economics aspect of it. I travel through space carrying waste from an overpopulated planet to a planet that grows food and bam, money. I sell cigarettes to an outpost planet and swim in credits. Have to figure out what to research and when to keep the crew happy, decide how to make trips cost effective, and I hope to one day get a bigger ship! See boys, size does matter, and any woman who says otherwise is lying.

It's also a game I can keep on in the background while I am at work, and game throughout the day. I adore games like that. They don't run hot, they stay windowed in the background, and no sound is needed. Perfecto.

There are absolutely cons though. There's no manual save, only an autosave, so if you have one bad run, it can lose you hours worth of money. I read the developers did that on purpose, jerks.

The combat system I have yet to get the hang of. I figure I'll wait until I have a bigger ship and can load it with weapons and then I'll start fighting, so I have no real info there. It does remind me a bit of oldschool space shooters so far though.

And why is it, there are times when it will take entire loops around the solar system to get to a planet that is directly next to me? That's one of the worst issues for me. Makes some missions totally worthless and I lose all my profit.

I have also had the game crash twice in the 9 hours I've played so far. Apparently, from what I am reading, that makes me one of the lucky ones.

And lastly, the missions get old. I feel like I am doing the same things, over and over. I'm just hoping that it will change once I get into the out planets I guess.

So, I enjoy it, but I really like making money games. Now, if you don't mind, there's this guy who needs a four-leafed clover, and I have to get it to him, for the 19th time.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. But after putting a few hours into the campaign I just can't recommend this.

To start with, the research tree is horrible. You have to research the middle and outer rings to get to more planets in the same system. Why? Does my ship not have sensors? Do the stations not have starcharts?

The room research is the worst offender though. At some point, your crew is going to want shower. You have to research a bathrrom with a shower. So let me understand, we know how to build spacefaring ships but don't know how to include a shower in the bathroom? Or a kitchen, medbay, gym, etc. In my opinion, this is just stupid. All of the rooms should have been unlocked from the start and research should have been applied to upgrading the efficiency of your existing rooms.

Next is travelling between planets. The pathfinding is mediocre at best and will do things that make no sense. I've had it where planets that were in the same wedge (think of the solar system divided into slices, like a pizza) but only 2 orbits apart take 7 days to travel...all because the pathfinding decided that my ship would fly counter-clockwise around the entire system instead of just doing a straight shot to the planet. Oddly enough, exiting the game and then reloading the save made the game recalculate the path to a still inefficient 4.5 days.

Combat. I tried it once. On a 1 skull rated difficulty. Which turned into an utter failure. The lack of ability to manually control your flight path is a terrible decision. It would've been ok if there were more choices available to you. Right now, all you can do is close the distance, fly circles around your enemy (doesn't work well enough), and flee. Oh...there's an evade button you can use but all that does is move the ship to the side briefly. Which doesn't work well.

The game has potential but in its current state, that's all I can say about it. Wait for demo to try it out or for the price to be slashed during a sale if you're interested.

Late Game is somewhat dissapointing but I will come back to that in the final overview

I think late game would have benefited from having the crew being bigger and having interactions with each other

but overall, I'd really reccomend this to anyone who loves Arcade Style Simulation games.

Totally worth playing. A quirky little space trading/piracy sim with great art and a whole heap of procedurally-generated content, which is very much in vogue these days.

That said, here are three things you should know about Cosmonautica:

~Performance will gradually decrease until the game crashes after about 2 hours. Fortunately, in only takes about 10 seconds to re-start, and you'll always come back to a fresh auto-save.

~Travelling is a huge time-sink, and you'll be travelling every few minutes. Encouraging the player to get up and walk away from the computer every 3 minutes is a pretty substantial design flaw.

~It doesn't have anything like an end-game. You just have to decide that you've beat the game after you have all the money.

reviewText:
I had high expectations for Cosmonautica because its cartoonish art style and the space exploration gameplay were very attractive. However, after playing the game for 12 hours, I must say that the gameplay mechanics are huge disappointments because they seriously lack tactical depth and variety.

This game is mainly composed of 2 gameplay components: 1) space combat and 2) interplanetary trading. The mechanics of these 2 components, unfortunately, are completely broken.

First of all, for space combat, I can simply use 2 words to summarize it: Use torpedoes. That's it. I'm not kidding. You just need to equip your space ship with tons of torpedoes and you'll win every space combat in this game. Don't waste your time and money on other types of weapons.

For space trading, I can just use 4 words to summarize it: Trade high-priced goods. That's it. The profits from trading expensive goods are so high that there's literally no reason at all to trade mid- and low-priced commodities in this game.

So, if you want to be successful in Cosmonautica, it's just very very simple: use torpedoes (in combats) and trade high-priced commodities (in trading). The gameplay mechanics are just overly simplistic and broken. Honestly, after playing this game for about 5 hours, I already got very bored. I kept playing for another 7 hours because I didn't want to waste my $15 spent on the game. I wish the new Steam refund policy had been in effect when I bought this disappointing title.

Conclusion: Cosmonautica has beautiful graphics, but its gameplay mechanics fail miserably.

My review score: 5/10

Trying to get some early game money, still trying to fill spots on my crew with very limited cash.  I take a 1 skull mission to kill a pirate.  Right before the fight, one of the many â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ random events makes my repairman destroy one of my rooms then leaves them sick with a hangover.  Fight starts and I can't repair anything.  I also find out that my newly installed turret can't even scratch the enemy.  I retreat from the fight, and get docked $1500 for a failed mission.  Take the loss, try to recover.  Get a speeding ticket for $2500.  Try to recover again?  Don't have enough money left to invest in trade to make profit.  Try to sell pieces of ship to start over?  Does matter, crew is tantrum spiraling.  Money goes into negative, impossible to recover.

The game is all about having enough money to make money.  But you quickly find out you can't reliably make money in the beginning, as the only forms of trade that can actually make profit (Such as computers) don't restock/empty fast enough to be continually used (at least in the Tutorial campaign).  This forces you into relying on missions for reliable income, which aren't as reliable as you'd think. Almost all item shipping missions seem to be smuggling with 50+/-% failure rates (you actually lose money and waste time each time you fail).  Having a hacker in your crew might help offset this, but I never got the chance to test it due to expenses.  NPC transport missions require you to take up extra room on your already tiny ship with passenger seats, which with the already lack of money and space, may be difficult to aquire/fit.  Pirate killing missions require a good weapons/shield setup (as above mentioned), which is expensive early game and again, takes up lots of ship room.

Etc etc, long story short, TL;DR:  My experience was extremely frustrating and I would never recommend this, or any other Luck based game, to anyone.  Any strategy/simulation/eyecandy/humor the game has, feels masked by the potential of bad luck being able to just end your game at any time, wasting hours of grinding.  Not my cup of tea.

Well, it's charming and fun to play, but unfortunately the gameplay still has some kinks in it. This game still needs some love and polish, and iterative playtesting, but since I'm actually enjoying myself playing it I have to recommend it.

The good: it's fun to recruit a crew, train them up to be an efficient fighting machine, and travel the cosmos in search of fun and profit. This game gets those basics right. And the presentation is absolutely charming. And the solar systems use simple orbital mechanics! As a Kerbal Space Program player that's pretty damn awesome to see.

There are some problems that stop the game short of true greatness. Aside from the storyline missions, the gameplay is rather repetitive. When you've seen one system, you've seen them all, especially if you're a combat vessel rather than a trader. There are only a handful of basic missions, and you see the same ones over and over again.

There are also some balance/tuning issues that need to be addressed.

For one thing, fighting other vessels produces OUTRAGEOUS profit, far beyond anything else. This is because when you're beating the enemy they hail you to surrender and offer money and cargo to let them live. That money is always much, much higher than any possible mission reward you were getting to fight them. A simple bounty mission might be around 7,500 credits, while the ransom is likely to be 42,000!

Trading still doesn't produce much profit unless you go for the higher value goods. That's fine, except that when you sell goods to a station they remain in that station and slowly disappear over time (as the inhabitants use them up, presumably). The problem is that this decay rate is far too slow. You end up stuffing the planet full of goods and unable to sell because everyone is still working their way through the last batch. Basically, you have to sell to planets other than ones that actually have a demand for your goods, and I'm reasonably sure that you could glut a whole system without much trouble.

Some of the crew roles simply aren't useful, ditto ship rooms. There's a galley that requires a cook to operate, but the starting food vending machine is more than adequate for a full crew, and by the time you've researched the tech for the galley it's a simple matter to research the upgrade that makes the galley operate without a cook. Since upgrades are done by researching a technology, and that technology is used by different unlocks or upgrades, it's quite easy to inadvertently unlock automating the galley because you unlocked the prereq techs for other benefits they unlock.

Same story with medics/medbay - the pill dispenser works just as well, doesn't require training, and the medbay gets automated by upgrades.

Crew preferences and interactions is a nice idea in theory but it's simple enough to get crewmates who all like the same food and then you never have to worry about it again.

There isn't enough different mission text, so missions will repeat constantly. It's a very minor quibble, but it gets annoying reading the same description over and over and over.


Basically, the game isn't balanced. The result is there's no real incentive to do anything other than what is most effective (ie, fight ships for outrageous ransoms). In a way you're punished for taking alternate approaches because they're so dismally ineffective by comparison.

It feels like this game has tremendous potential that could be unlocked by gameplay tuning. This would turn it from a pretty good" game to an amazingly fantastic one. That said
